comments:
Political Science 253 addresses the Arab-Israeli dispute from 1948 to the present as a vehicle for understanding how domestic and global political processes interact to shape, contain, or aggravate Middle Eastern wars between states, as well as between states and non-state actors.  Attention is given toward the end of the course to alternative ideas about possible resolution of the conflict as well as to the increasingly prominent argument that, in this case, there is no solution.

Students reported learning a lot from this course. They found the readings to be "interesting" and "thought-provoking."

Students described Professor Lustick as a "dynamic" and "incredible" professor. They appreciated his extensive knowledge and his presentation of the material in "a very objective manner." Students enjoyed going to lectures and found lecture discussion to be "insightful" and "interesting."

Students found this course to be "extremely difficult." There was an extensive amount of reading each week and exams were very hard.
